lesson.name: Lesson 2.7 Teacher Guide: Representing Situations with Inequalities

page.title: 2.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative 

Prior to this point, students have worked primarily with equations in one and two variables. In this lesson, they shift their attention to inequalities. Here and in the next two lessons, students interpret, write, and find solutions to inequalities in one variable. The activities here are grounded in contexts, and the ideas build on the work students have done in grade 7 (TEKS 7.10).

The focus of this lesson is on interpreting and writing inequalities that represent the constraints in various situations. As students consider key quantities in a situation, select variables to represent them, and decide whether multiple inequalities (and which ones) are needed, they engage in aspects of mathematical modeling.

In future lessons, students will use the insights from this lesson to find and interpret the solutions to inequalities that model situations.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Interpret and write inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Write inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A5(B) solve linear inequalities in one variable, including those for which the application of the distributive property is necessary and for which variables are included on both sides.

Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.

Lesson Activities 

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 2.7.1: Understanding Inequality Symbols
  • 2.7.2: Identifying Constraints in Inequalities
    • 2.7.2: Self Check 
    • 2.7.2: Additional Resources 
  • 2.7.3: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints
    • 2.7.3: Self Check 
    • 2.7.3: Additional Resources 
  • 2.7.4: Writing More Inequalities

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 2.7.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • N/A

Required Preparation

  • N/A

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary:

  • constraints

New Vocabulary:

  • inequality

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their growth mindset.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Adaptability Advantage
  • Guided Mastery

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Growth Mindset from Character Lab.

page.title: 2.7.1: Understanding Inequality Symbols
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

In this activity, students recall the meaning of inequality symbols (<, >, ≤, and ≥) and the meaning of “solutions to an inequality.” They are reminded that an inequality in one variable can have a range of values that make the statement true. Students also pay attention to the value that is at the boundary of an inequality and consider whether it is or isn’t a solution to an inequality.

Launch

Give students 1–2 minutes of quiet work time. Follow with a whole-class discussion. 

Student-Facing Statement 

  1. Match each inequality to the meaning of a symbol within it.

    1. \( h>50 \)
    2. \( h \leq 20 \)
    3. \( 30 \geq h \)
    • less than or equal to
    • greater than
    • greater than or equal to

  2. Is 25 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

  3. Is 40 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

  4. Is 30 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

Student Response

  1. Answers
    • a: 2, \( h > 50 \): “greater than”
    • b: 1, \( h ≤ 20 \): “less than or equal to”
    • c: 3, \( 30 ≥ h \): “greater than or equal to”
  2. Yes; 25 is a solution to \( 30 ≥ h \) because 30 is greater than or equal to 25.
  3. No; 40 is not a solution to any of the inequalities because 40 does not make any of the inequalities true when substituted in for \( h \).
  4. Yes; 30 is a solution to \( 30 ≥ h \) because, while \( 30 > 30 \) is not a true statement, \( 30 = 30 \) is a true statement.

Activity Synthesis

Draw students’ attention to the last inequality \( (30≥h) \). Make sure students see that, even though the symbol is read “greater than or equal to,” it doesn’t mean that we’re looking for values that are greater than or equal to 30. The statement reads “30 is greater than or equal to \( h \),” which means \( h \) must be less than or equal to 30.

Next, ask students how they know whether each of those numbers (the 50, 20, and 30, or the boundary values) is a solution to the inequality. Emphasize that we can test those boundary values the same way we test other values: by checking if they make the statement true.

Display these equations in one variable for all to see: \( h=50 \), \( h=20 \), and \( 30=h \). Discuss with students how these equations are different from the inequalities in one variable (aside from the fact that the symbols are different). Highlight the idea that there is only one value that could make each equation true, but there is a range of values that can make each inequality true.

page.title: 2.7.2: Identifying Constraints in Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity prompts students to interpret several inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation. To explain what the letters in the inequalities mean in the given context, students cannot simply match the numbers in the verbal descriptions and those in the inequalities. They must attend carefully to the symbols and any operations and reason both quantitatively and abstractly.

The work here also engages students in an aspect of mathematical modeling. Although students do not choose the variables to represent the essential features of a situation, they think carefully about and explain how the given models do represent the key features of the given situation.

As students discuss with their partners, listen for those who could interpret the inequalities clearly and accurately. Ask them to share their interpretations later.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Give them a few minutes of quiet think time, followed by some time to share their thinking with their partner.

Student-Facing Statement

Seniors in a high school student council are trying to develop a budget for the Senior Dance. The revenue from ticket sales needs to cover the cost of the meals and entertainment and also make a profit of at least $200 to be contributed to the school. 

Here is some information they have gathered:

  • Last year, 120 people attended. It was a success and is expected to be even bigger this year. Up to 200 people will attend.
  • There needs to be at least 1 chaperone for every 20 students.
  • The ticket price cannot exceed $20 per person.

 Here are some inequalities the seniors wrote about the situation. Each letter stands for one quantity in the situation. Determine what is meant by each letter.

  1. \( t ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 120 ≤ p ≤ 200 \)
  3. \( pt − m ≥ 200 \)
  4. \( c \geq \frac{p}{20} \)

Student Response

Sample response (an interpretation of the meaning of each letter and an interpretation of the mathematical statement are included):

  1. \( t ≤ 20 \) means that the ticket price, \( t \), must be less than or equal to $20.
  2. \( 120 ≤ p ≤ 200 \) means that between 120 and 200 people are expected to attend (120 is less than or equal to the number of people; the number of people is less than or equal to 200). \( p \) represents the number of people attending the dance.
  3. \( pt − m ≥ 200 \) means that the total amount collected from ticket sales in dollars, \( pt \), minus the cost of meals and entertainment in dollars, \( m \), must be greater than or equal to $200.
  4. \( c \geq \frac{p}{20} \) means that the number of chaperones, \( c \), must be at least \( \frac{1}{20} \) of the number of students attending.

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Kiran says we should add the constraint \( t ≥ 0 \).

  1. What is the reasoning behind this constraint?
  2. What other “natural constraint” like this should be added?

Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may relate an inequality to a written description simply based on the letter chosen for the variable (for example, “people” begins with “p”). Push these students to explain how the inequalities express the quantities and constraints in the written descriptions.

For students unfamiliar with the notation \( 120≤p≤200 \), explain that this is a way of stating \( 120≤p \) and \( p≤200 \).

Activity Synthesis 

Invite previously identified students to share their responses. Make sure students understand why the symbols accurately represent the constraints in the situation.

For the last two inequalities, make sure students see how the operations represent the constraints on profit and on the number of chaperones.

 If needed, use numbers to illustrate the relationship between variables. For example, to help students make sense of \( c \geq \frac{p}{20} \), ask: “How many chaperones are needed if there are 120 students?” (at least \( \frac{120}{20} \) or 6 chaperones, or \( c \geq \frac{120}{20} \)) “180 students?” (at least \( \frac{180}{20} \) or 9 chaperones, or \( c \geq \frac{180}{20} \))

Support for English Language Learners

Use this routine to support reading comprehension of this problem. Use the first read to orient students to the situation. Ask students to describe what the situation is about without using numbers (students planning a budget for an upcoming special event). Take time to discuss the meaning of unfamiliar terms at this time (Senior Dance, budget, chaperone, profit, etc.). Use the second read to identify quantities and relationships. Ask students what can be counted or measured without focusing on the values (number of people who attended in the past, maximum number of people expected this year, ratio of chaperones to students, maximum ticket price, minimum amount of profit needed, etc.). After the third read, ask students to brainstorm possible strategies to answer the questions. This will help students make sense of language used to describe situations involving inequalities.

Support for Students with Disabilities

Representation: Internalize Comprehension. Provide appropriate reading accommodations and supports to ensure student access to written directions, word problems, and other text-based content.

Supports accessibility for: Language; Conceptual processing


2.7.2: Self Check

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

A zookeeper feeds the tigers a meal of rabbits and chickens. The average rabbit weighs 4 pounds, and the average chicken weighs 5 pounds. Each tiger must eat at least 15 pounds of meat per day.


The zookeeper writes the inequality \( 4x + 5y ≥ 15 \) to represent a tiger’s daily diet.


What is meant by the letter \( y \) in the inequality above?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

the number of rabbits a tiger eats daily

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of rabbits a tiger eats daily is represented by \( x \). The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

the average weight of a rabbit

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The average weight of a rabbit is 4 pounds. The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

the number of chickens a tiger eats daily

That’s correct! Check yourself: The letter \( y \) represents the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

the average weight of a chicken

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The average weight of a chicken is 5 pounds. The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

2.7.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Translate to an Inequality

To translate English sentences into inequalities, we need to recognize the phrases that indicate the inequality. Some words are easy, like “more than” and “less than.” But others are not as obvious. The table shows some common phrases that indicate inequalities.
> > ≥ ≥ < < ≤ ≤
is greater than

is more than

is larger than

exceeds		 is greater than or equal to

is at least

is no less than

is the minimum		 is less than

is smaller than

has fewer than

is lower than		 is less than or equal to

is at most

is no more than

is the maximum

Example

Translate each phrase to an inequality.

Twenty-seven less than x \(\underbrace{is\;at\;least}\) 48
\(x-17\geq48\)

"is at least" means \( \geq \)
5 more than z \(\underbrace{is\;lower\;than}\) 52

\(z + 5 < 52\)

"is at least" means \( \geq \)

Try It: Translate to an Inequality 

Translate the following sentences into inequalities.

  1. Nineteen less than \( p \) is no less than 47.
  2. Four more than \( a \) is at most 15.

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution 

Here is how to translate these sentences into inequalities:

  1. Solution: \( p - 19 ≥ 47 \)
  2. Solution: \( a + 4 ≤ 15 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 2.7.3: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

Previously, students interpreted given inequalities and made sense of them in terms of a situation. In this activity, students write inequalities to represent the constraints in a situation. Students identify key quantities and relationships and think about ways to represent them. In doing so, they engage in an aspect of mathematical modeling.

As students work, look for those who represent the same constraint using different inequalities or equations. For example, to represent the total weight that the elevator could carry, some students may write \( w≤1,500 \), some may write \( 1,500≥w \), and others may write \( w<1,500 \) or \( w=1,500 \). Ask students with contrasting statements to share their responses later.

Launch

Keep students in groups of 2.

Student-Facing Statement

An elevator car in a skyscraper can hold at most 15 people. For safety reasons, each car can carry a maximum of 1,500 kg. On average, an adult weighs 70 kg and a child weighs 35 kg. Assume that each person carries 4 kg of gear with them.

  1. Write as many equations and inequalities as you can think of to represent the constraints in this situation. Be sure to specify the meaning of any letters that you use. (Avoid using the letters \( z \), \( m \), or \( g \).)
  2.  Trade your work with a partner and read each other’s equations and inequalities.
    • Explain to your partner what you think their statements mean, and listen to their explanation of yours.
    • Make adjustments to your equations and inequalities so that they are communicated more clearly.
  3. Rewrite your equations and inequalities so that they would work for a different building where:
    • an elevator car can hold at most \( z \) people
    • each car can carry a maximum of \( m \) kilograms
    • each person carries \( d \) kg of gear

Video: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints Solution 

Watch the following video to further explain the solution to the activity you just completed. Do you have any questions? Play the video again or ask your teacher for clarification.


Student Response

  1. Answers vary. Sample Responses:
    • \( p ≤ 15 \), where \( p \) represents the number of people in an elevator car
    • \( a + c ≤ 15 \), where \( a \) represents the number of adults and \( c \) represents the number of children in an elevator car.
    • \( w ≤ 1,500 \), where \( w \) represents the weight in kilograms in one elevator car.
    • \( w = 70a + 35c + 4a + 4c \)
    • \( 70a + 35c + 4a + 4c ≤ 1,500 \)
    • \( 74a + 39c ≤ 1,500 \)
  2. No response required.
  3. Answers vary. Sample Responses:
    • \( p ≤ z \)
    • \( a + c ≤ z \)
    • \( w ≤ m \)
    • \( w = 70a + 35c + da + dc \)
    • \( 70a + 35c + da + dc ≤ m \)
    • \( (70 + d)a + (35 + d)c ≤ m \)

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students who use a variable for the number of adults and another for the number of children may have trouble accounting for the weight of the gear because it applies to both groups. Calculating the weight of a specific combination of adults and children (with their gear) may help.

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their equations and inequalities, starting with those that are more concrete (from the first question) and ending with the ones that are more abstract (from the last question).

Emphasize that the same constraints may be accurately represented by statements of different forms. Consider reading aloud the different inequalities that represent the same constraint. For example, if \( w \) represents the total weight:

  • \( w≤1,500 \) can be read: “The total weight is less than or equal to 1,500 kilograms” or “The total weight is at most 1,500 kilograms.”
  • \( 1,500≥w \) can be read: “Fifteen hundred kilograms is greater than or equal to the total weight.”
  • \( w<1,500 \) or \( w=1,500 \) can be read: “The total weight is less than 1,500 kilograms, or it is equal to 1,500 kilograms.”

For constraints that involve multiple quantities, some students may write, for instance, \( 74a+39c≤1,500 \), while others may write \( 70a+4a+35c+4c≤1,500 \). Ask students why these expressions are equivalent, encouraging them to use the context in their explanation. Point out that although a constraint can be written in different ways, writing it using fewer terms may be more convenient and may allow us to gain certain insights about the situation.

Support for English Language Learners

Use this routine to support whole-class discussion. As students share their responses, amplify and record any words and phrases that describe the meaning of each equation or inequality on a display. Call students’ attention to the different ways the constraints are represented by language in context and equations or inequalities of different forms.


2.7.3: Self Check

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Serena is running a juice shop. Oranges cost $2 per pound. She can spend at most $64 per day on oranges. If \( p \) represents the number of pounds of oranges Serena can buy per day, which of the following inequalities is true?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\( 2p ≤ 64 \)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The statement \( 2p ≤ 64 \) means she can spend at most $64 at $2 per pound.

\( 2p < 64 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This statement needs to include spending exactly $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).

\( 2p ≥ 64 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cost cannot be greater than $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).

\( 2p > 64 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cost cannot exceed $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).


2.7.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Applications with Linear Inequalities 

Many real-life situations require us to solve inequalities. The method we will use to solve applications with linear inequalities is very much like the one we used when we solved applications with equations.

We will read the problem and make sure all the words are understood. Next, we will identify what we are looking for and assign a variable to represent it. We will restate the problem in one sentence to make it easy to translate into an inequality. 

Example 

Dawn won a mini-grant of $4,000 to buy tablet computers for her classroom. The tablets she would like to buy cost $254.12 each, including tax and delivery. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of tablets Dawn can buy.

Solution

Step 1. Read the problem.

Step 2. Identify what you are looking for.

the maximum number of tablets Dawn can buy

Step 3. Name what you are looking for.

Choose a variable to represent that quantity.

Let \( n= \) the number of tablets.

Step 4. Translate. Write a sentence that gives the information to find it.

$254.12 times the number of tablets is no more than $4,000.

Translate into an inequality.

\( 254.12n ≤ 4000 \)

Try It: Applications with Linear Inequalities

  1. Angie has $20 to spend on juice boxes for her son’s preschool picnic. Each pack of juice boxes costs $2.63. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of packs, \( p \), she can buy.
  2. Daniel wants to surprise his girlfriend with a birthday party at her favorite restaurant. It will cost $42.75 per person for dinner, including tip and tax. His budget for the party is $500. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of people, \( n \), Daniel can have at the party.
Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to write an inequality for each situation:
  1. \( 2.63p ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 42.75n ≤ 500 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 2.7.4: Writing More Inequalities
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student-Facing Statement 

Han has a budget of $25 to buy grapes. Write inequalities to represent the number of pounds of grapes that Han could buy in each situation:

  • Grapes cost $1.99 per pound.
  • Grapes cost $2.49 per pound.
  • Grapes cost $\(c\) per pound.

Student Response

Let \( g \) represent the number of pounds of grapes.

  • \( 1.99g ≤ 25 \)
  • \( 2.49g ≤ 25 \)
  • \( cg ≤ 25 \)

Response to Student Thinking 

More Chances 

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool-down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool-down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 2.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1-2, use the following passage:

A runner is training for a marathon. She runs more than 4 days each week. Each day,
she runs between 12 and 15 miles. The marathon is 3 months away at the most.

1. What does the inequality d > 4 represent?

  1. the number of miles in a marathon
  2. the number of miles the runner runs each day
  3. the number of months away the marathon is
  4. the number of days the runner runs each week

ANSWER: the number of days the runner runs each week

2. What does the inequality 12 ≤ m ≤ 15 represent?

  1. the number of miles in a marathon
  2. the number of miles the runner runs each day
  3. the number of months away the marathon is
  4. the number of days the runner runs each week

ANSWER: the number of miles the runner runs each day

For questions 3-8, write an inequality to represent the constraint given.

3. There are less than 4 patients, p, in the waiting room.

  1. p < 4
  2. p > 4
  3. p ≤ 4
  4. p ≥ 4

ANSWER: p < 4

4. There are no more than 6 cats, c, in the yard.

  1. c > 6
  2. c ≤ 6
  3. c < 6
  4. c ≥ 6

ANSWER: c < 6

5. There are no less than 7 markers, m, in the drawer.

  1. m > 7
  2. m ≤ 7
  3. m < 7
  4. m ≥ 7

ANSWER: m ≥ 7

6. The basket has between 12 and 19 eggs, e.

  1. 12 > e and e > 19
  2. 12 ≥ e and e ≥ 19
  3. e ≤ 19
  4. 12 < e < 19

ANSWER:  \(12 < e < 19 \)

7. The total sales of tickets to a show is more than $68. An adult ticket, a, costs $8 and a children’s ticket, c, is $3.

  1. \( 8a + 3c ≤ 68 \)
  2. \( 8a + 3c ≥ 68 \)
  3. \( 8a + 3c < 68 \)
  4. \( 8a + 3c > 68 \)

ANSWER: \( 8a + 3c > 68 \)

8. There needs to be at least 1 pound of clay, c, for every 4 students, s.

  1. \( p ≥ \frac s4 \)
  2. \( p > \frac s4 \) 
  3. \( p < \frac s4 \)
  4. \( p ≤ \frac s4 \)

ANSWER: \( p ≥ \frac s4 \)

For questions 9-11, use the following passage:

A doctor sees between 7 and 12 patients each day. On Mondays and Tuesdays, the
appointment times are 15 minutes. On Wednesdays and Thursdays, they are 30 minutes long. On Fridays, they are one hour long. The doctor works for no more than 8 hours a day. Here are some inequalities that represent this situation.

0.25 ≤ y ≤ 1                 7 ≤ x ≤ 12                    xy ≤ 8

9. What does the variable x represent?

  1. the number of patients the doctor sees each day
  2. the part of an hour that each appointment lasts
  3. the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day.
  4. the number of patients the doctor sees in a week

ANSWER: the number of patients the doctor sees each day

10. What does the variable y represent?

  1. the number of patients the doctor sees each day
  2. the part of an hour that each appointment lasts
  3. the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day.
  4. the number of patients the doctor sees in a week

ANSWER: the part of an hour that each appointment lasts

11. What does the expression xy in the last inequality mean in this situation?

  1. the number of patients the doctor sees each day
  2. the part of an hour that each appointment lasts
  3. the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day.
  4. the number of patients the doctor sees in a week

ANSWER: the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day

For questions 12-14, use the following passage:

Arnav wants to build a dog house. He makes a list of the materials needed:

  1. At least 60 square feet of plywood for the surfaces
  2. At least 36 feet of wood planks for the frame of the dog house
  3. Between 1 and 2 quarts of paint

Arnav's budget is $65. Plywood costs $0.70 per square foot, planks of wood cost $0.10 per foot, and paint costs $8 per quart.

12. Which inequality represents the square feet of plywood needed?

  1. p ≥ 60
  2. p ≥ 36
  3. 1 ≤ p ≤ 2

ANSWER: p ≥ 60

13. Which inequality represents the number of wood planks needed?

  1. w ≥ 60
  2. 1 ≤ w ≤ 2
  3. w ≥ 36

ANSWER: w ≥ 36

14. Which inequality represents the number of quarts of paint needed?

  1. q ≥ 60
  2. 1 ≤ q ≤ 2
  3. q ≥ 36

ANSWER: 1 ≤ q ≤ 2

page.title: 2.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
Solicit from students any advantages and disadvantages for representing constraints as inequalities. Some advantages students might bring up:

  • Compared to written words, inequalities are a simpler and quicker way to describe what is happening in a situation.
  • It is easier to see what values a certain quantity could or could not take when the constraint is written with symbols and numbers.

Possible disadvantages:

  • Unless we know what the variables stand for, we can’t be sure about the meaning of an inequality.
  • If we don’t recall what the symbols mean or how to read them, we can’t access the information.

Next, invite students to share some advice for students who might just be learning to write inequalities to represent constraints. What should they pay attention to? What are some potential sources of confusion or error they should look out for? Students might mention that the following are important things to attend to:

  • Specifying the meaning of each variable
  • Not using the same variable to represent different quantities
  • Making sure that the correct symbols are used to represent relationships
  • Using words to read each inequality to make sure that it fully represents a constraint
